newsitem.title: USA: Arizona Public sees N.M. plant back Aug 29.
newsitem.headline: Arizona Public sees N.M. plant back Aug 29.

text.p: Arizona Public Service expects to restart a 745 megawatt (MW) coal-fired unit at its power plant near Farmington, N.M. on Aug 29, the company said Friday.
The unit, part of the Four Corners facility, was shut Aug 22 to repair a leaking boiler tube.
"It's going to be a week," said company spokesman Bruce Richardson, when asked how long the unit would be out of service.
"They're in the tough area of the boiler," he said, referring to engineers' repair work being carried out in the boiler's reheater section.
Arizona Public Service, a subsidiary of Pinnacle West Capital Corp, has a 15 percent share in Four Corners' units 4 and 5.
Edison International's Southern California Edison Co has a 48 percent interest in units 4 and 5, each of which have a generation capacity of 745 MW.
Arizona Public Service, a subsidiary of Pinnacle West Capital Corp, has 100 percent ownership of Four Corners units 1, 2 and 3.
Units 1 and 2 each have a generation capacity 170 MW, while unit 3 has a capacity of 220 MW.
